tips: In Spanish, adjectives typically come after the noun they modify.
Spanish has two types of 'to be': 'ser' for permanent states and 'estar' for temporary conditions.
Spanish verbs change their endings based on the subject pronoun.
examples: The red car → El coche rojo
I am tall (permanent) → Yo soy alto
I am tired (temporary) → Yo estoy cansado

tips: In English, adjectives typically come before the noun they modify.
English uses 'to be' for both permanent and temporary states.
English verbs typically don't change their form based on the subject.
examples: El coche rojo → The red car
Yo soy alto → I am tall
Yo estoy cansado → I am tired

en-fr: In French, adjectives can come before or after the noun depending on the adjective.
fr-en: In English, adjectives typically come before the noun they modify.
en-de: In German, adjectives change their endings based on the gender, number, and case of the noun.
de-en: In English, adjectives do not change their form based on the noun.
